comments.commentBody: How do you know the startups were because of ACA?  Were the startups because formerly employed people realized they had no hope of finding a job, so they may as well try to create their own business? Do they have the business acumen to succeed?     Long term we may see ACA create jobs, for the short term the turmoil created was so disruptive many took a wait and see attitude - which means delay investing in the future - pull back and purchase bonds you know will lose lose value compared to inflation.  In other words don't invest for the future, invest to keep what little you have acquired and minimize loss.    An environment of hope encourages investment for new ideas and projects; the opposite of US for the last 6 years.     Business and banks are now scapegoats and villains for Obama to attack.     Yet wall street continues to poor money into the democratic coffers?  Why?  because although the democrats vilify them, the democrats give them everything they need - Quantitative easing, withhold democratic powers to stock holders and maintain the big business status quo so they maintain their wealth.
Most startups go bust,so I’m not so sure that Americans leaving their jobs because they’re not chained to their jobs is a good thing .

There are more startups after Obamacare became effective. American workers no longer have to be chained to their jobs for health insurance. I believe Obamacare will stimulate our economic growth in the short and long run. We will get used to the fact that Obamacare creates jobs.

roy, i am a physician. please show me where these scientific studies are, I'd really like to see them.  Of course studies aren't scientific because someone who is a scientist writes them. they are scientific because someone has studied the outcomes of a certain treatment (in this case vaccination) and found that those vaccinated are more or less likely to have a certain outcome. I know that people vaccinated are more likely to not get the disease they are being vaccinated against. some small (very small )amount may have allergic reactions to the shots. Some small number of children receiving rotavirus vaccine may have an increased risk of intususseption. another small number receiving live vaccines (mmr and chickenpox) may actually get a very mild rash . Many vaccines can cause a little swelling and a few may cause a short lived fever. Please share with me these other well known reactions that should be easy to identify as millions of american children are vaccinated every year.  ( How many damaged children can exist without medical science acknowledging them, to make vaccination a a bad risk/benefit?  I'd like to see evidence of any such children. I couldn't live with myself if I knew that these vaccines were really  "damaging" children!) Really, please someone tell me, because I believe I am helping children when I vaccinate them, and if you have evidence (not speculation) otherwise, I'd really like to see it.
Yes, SCOTUS provides the interpretations; but not in a vacuum.

Let's be realistic here: No guns belong in an educational environment anywhere. Neither do knives, or any other weapon. They cannot add anything to the primary task of learning.  If Mick's reasoning is to have merit, then everywhere is the appropriate place for guns because someone might do something bad. That ignores the fact that every credible study shows the presence of weapons increases the likelihood of conflict and a confrontation that results in life-threatening injuries.  Let's add into that toxic mix the requirements for carrying a weapon, let alone demonstrating the ability and judgement to use it: None.  Even for concealed weapons permits, the requirement is a 3-hour safety course, the firing of one, ONE round and that's it evermore. We're not that frivolous in issuing licenses to drive, yet somehow its OK to give them a weapon capable of killing many in short order with virtually no demonstrated qualifications or recurrent training?  These are the conditions that will save us? No. These are the conditions that put us all at greater risk.  Keep your Second Amendment rights in your home, your car, your target range, your personal space, but keep it out of the public classrooms, restaurants, and other places where weapons have no role.  Respect others freedoms as much as you sincerely believe in your own.  That's responsible gun ownership.  And yes, I have 10 and wouldn't think of making anyone uncomfortable by bringing them where they don't belong!

And Illinois, New York City and State, New Jersey and California are fine examples of good financial stewardship. All are Democrat run and have been for decades. All are unable to meet employee pension obligations and have deteriorating infrastructure yet have the highest real estate and income tax rates in the nation. All are losing citizens who have given up and are moving South and West with the exception of California which is losing businesses going East.

We just bought a couple hundred acres in Colorado to grow heirloom apples. All three of our families are moving there from Louisiana because Louisiana has gone insane!

Please don't tell me that republicans have any power in Colorado, we thought it was one of the sane states, that's why we chose it.

Let me tell the people of Colorado just how horrible it is to live in a republican run state, it is almost as bad as third world countries with spotty utilities, hazardous, dilapidated roads and bridges, towns that can't even keep the street lights on because they are so broke from republican mismanagement. There is a story here in the NYT today about how Bobby Jindal has bankrupted Louisiana and crippled hospitals and higher education, you do NOT want any republicans in office!!!

Look at Kansas and Florida and Mississippi, all republican southern states are in trouble, trust me you do NOT want to go there, turn out and vote like your life depends on it because if republicans are in charge, it does.

Scalia claims that he is a "strict constructionist," that he goes back to the words of the writers of any Constitutional provision, while they were composing, to discern what their intent was; no interpretation required. And then he proceeds to interpret so aggressively that he raises more questions than he settles. That's just him.

But the concept he claims to work from is valid nonetheless. The first draft of the 2A was created in the Richmond Convention to Ratify, held over some 22 days and generating extensive notes. An excellent summary of the proceedings can be found in the following Law Review article. I would recommend skipping right to the section about the convention and then the rest as desired:
http://lawreview.law.ucdavis.edu/issues/31/2/Articles/DavisVol31No2_Bogu...
Nixon and his southern strategy 1968, it has been down hill ever since.

BambiB:
Oh, please. The people already ARE the ultimate power in America. And what's more, we overthrow our government in pieces, every two years, four years, and six years. No gunfire required.

Take one teensy little shot at our duly-elected Government, and that would make you a traitor by definition; the enemy of all of the rest of us.
Yes, we witness what "they" do.  But no 'barbaric' videos of what our bombs do to the bodies of men, women and children.

Meanwhile the vast oil wealth of the region is controlled by handful of "royal families" who came to power under the auspices of British Imperialism and are now maintained on their thrones by US Central Command. Instead of socio-economic development and industrialization of the region, the wealth is siphoned off in payoffs to Western arms merchants and bankers and Bechtel to build royal palaces. This is why the devastating retaliation of 9/11 took place and not because of "American freedom".
Wrong. Vaccines are a surprisingly unprofitable business. Most of big pharma stays away from them. Vaccine production is more humanitarian than most people would imagine.

Duh, no, pharmaceutical companies are forced to manufacture these drugs that have long been off patent, because they are considered lifesaving.  They are expensive to manufacture and many pharma companies lose money on them.  Trust me, they'd rather devote those production lines to Viagra.

That "they" are doing it for the money is one of the most beloved argument of those who love conspiracy theories.  You know, like "doctors keep people sick so they can make money".  I've never seen any of the people who claim this produce anything that shows the drug companies are make money on what vaccines and how much.  Of course, this might be because, as I understand it, drug companies are required by the government to produce the vaccines and not making any money. But why let facts get in the way of a good theory?

Of course some vaccines are highly effective and necessary.  However, Big Pharma long ago figured out it's a financial bonanza to get a new vaccine on the required list even if its urgency or utility is modest.

We will very quickly run out of jobs that cannot be off-shored or automated. Thus, we had better figure out a way to entice corporations to create jobs here that pay Americans decent wages. That is the only way the American worker is going to survive globalization.

That will most likely be done through tax incentives, regulatory streamlining, smarter unions, etc. -- in other words, better government where it matters.

Why the federal government hasn't struck a deal with corporations to create jobs is a mystery. Actually, it's borderline malfeasance.

And as we learned the Chinese company and laborers used substandard steel and the bridge is crumbling before it has even been finished. You get what you pay for, this is what many Americans have forgotten when buying the cheapest junk for the lowest price, whether it is a bridge or junk at Walmart.

I had some experience with unions when working with unionized companies. The Unions made huge mistakes over the years, especially by forcing senseless work rules onto companies, supporting members who simply were not able or willing to perform up to normal standards (especially the teachers' union), and by going for more and more future benefits, like retirement benefits, instead of fighting for increased wages today. BUT they could have survived and fixed these problems. They are disappearing due to a strategically planned well executed long term war against them by the plutocracy and their fully owned GOP and because the Democrats were spineless and did not have the guts to stand up for the Unions.

The present income inequality can be traced directly to globalization. When Corporations and business move millions of jobs overseas to take advantage of lower labor costs, the results is that the incomes of management and those who are shareholders increase, while the incomes of labor decrease. Assuming you are not so foolish as to imagine that globalization can somehow be significantly reversed, the obvious solution is to create jobs that cannot be sent off shore. Rebuilding and improving our infrastructures is a good place to start. Money to pay for the projects should come primarily from increased taxes on those who have benefitted most from globalization. Building infrastructure can hardly be accused of being a form of class warfare as everyone benefits from an improved infrastructure and a more fully employed nation.

When people are anxious they avoid risk will take the certainty of low interest.
Higher risk is rewarded with higher return.

Andrew,

Then why are asset values of the stock market and real estate markets inflated? Obviously, investors are buying these financial and real assets to lofty price levels: how does this reflect investor anxiety?
When asset values are low, you can say investors are anxious. Can you conclude the same thing when they are high?

It is clear to me that there is EXCESS CAPITAL in the economy. It goes roaming around even in dark corners looking for a return. But, many of these dark corners involve practices if revealed would show the nasty underbelly strip mining companies, ruining people's pensions, taking money from the poor and destroying the air/water we need to live on.

The economy is now so skewed toward capital that the flip side of the same coin, consumption, suffers. You cannot grow forever one side of that coin without growing the other.

It seems that the professor is saying that interest rates are low because people are anxious and uncertain. Does that make any sense? Future uncertainty commands a higher discount rate. This is standard finance theory and practice. When investors are cheerful of the future, discount rates go down and asset prices go up. The behavior of asset prices suggest that people are NOT unduly anxious about the future!
Someone please help me out because I must be missing something.
There is no uncertainty. The economy sucks. Recent gains have benefited the middle class only slightly. Raise the minimum wage. Dramatically. That will help.

Mr. Shiller, why don't you start another index. One that measures the 30-year fear index. Ask people, if they are afraid they may have grand children. Ask them; about our constant state of war. Terrorism . The dying environment. Our dying democracy. About engorged baby boomers demanding to suck the wealth from the future generations through uncontrolled medicade/medicare.
Yes, the rich worry me, but not as much as my neighbors.
Ask me, because I am worried.
I think I understand what you are saying here...but what do you mean by "time?" After all, everything is "just a matter of time." So: How much time?
cause
Didn't Obama call out the Supreme Court Justices in his 2010 State of the Union Address on their favorite ruling for Citizens United?

Anxiety among the masses is of benefit to the upper crust; less confident people are more pliable. When everyone and everything is a threat, nothing gets any focus. The one percenters like that. Pharmacuetical companies like that even more. Ask your doctor if "NumbTheWorry" is right for you!

Recall the comment attributed to Boss Tweed: "You can always pay half the poor people to kill the other half." That might not be literal... yet... but certainly divisive arguments and polarization are a reflection of trying to hold on to what we have... and a really convenient distraction.

Meanwhile, no point nothing percent interest rates naturally drive people to the Wall Street Casino. Low interest mortgages are useless to those who don't qualify, or who will cough up more in closing and other "costs" than the refinancing is worth.
Definition of a lie - an opinion on Fox (or on any conservative outlet) that you disagree with.

Nice shift. Have any Fox employees stolen war glory?
Or, we can stay with the current story. NBC's big star did.

You're fooling no one but yourself if you believe that Fox is the sole province of egotistical, bubble headed news readers masking as journalists, a term that is, sadly, merely a shell of what it once was.  This, indeed, is one of the problems - all real news organizations and their reporters should be held to a high standard but too many in the public are happy to look the other way if "their" preferred network or station does the vain, shallow, biased stuff and they can pretend that one side is bad (the other) and theirs is righteous and caring, just like their favored politicians. No different from poll after poll in which Americans lambaste Congress as being full of feckless crooks who should be term limited...but their guy is okay and should be reelected!

To quote Bill Maher if Brian Williams loses his NBC job he should have no trouble moving on to FOX where his ability to tell the same lie with a straight face over a period of years would no doubt put him in very good stead.

Indeed - anyone with training in safely using firearms, such as hunters, know the danger of letting untrained people address their feelings of powerlessness by strapping on a sidearm. I haven't been keeping count, but I expect that my odds of being killed by one of these untrained gun nuts are far greater than my odds of being killed by terrorists - even terrorists like Tim McVey. That's not even counting my odds of being shot by a frightened police officer who mistook me for someone carrying a firearm. (Remember the guy who got shot because he had an aluminum cane, which a police officer thought was a shotgun?)

On the other hand, I also face some danger from unvaccinated yoga enthusiasts. ;)
Taxation is theft when it is punitive. When used to punish the successful to support the mediocre.

The zero sum game is also the one pie game. If I get a bigger piece of pie then you must have a smaller one. People like Bill Gates, Steve Jobs and others didn't ask for a piece of the pie. Instead they brought another pie. They sold slices of that pie to others and when it became rarer to get a piece of the pie the buyers sold slices from their slices. There's lots of pies out there. They cost you to buy them or you can bring a new one to the party. If you are unable to do wither then you content yourself with knowing that you don't know how to make a pie instead of stealing someone else's pie.

Common good? We should let someone take what we work for for those who don't work? who don't complete their education or learn a trade? Who have children in their teens? What if we use the money to tie their tubes? Is that for the common good? Or those without a trade committing crimes we ensure a nice prison cell so the rest of society is safe from them? Your common good isn;t my common good. Your common good is an enabling attitude holding no one responsible for their actions. I don;t feel like paying for that.

Mr. Reich is right.  You can't keep tap dancing around this issue, because it's a zero sum game, and the only way to address it is through policies that begin to siphon wealth and income from the rich back to the middle class and poor.  The economy can only grow so fast, so we can't grow our way out of this problem, like the Republicans will surely propose.  The rich will just have to come on board with this, they can surely give up some of their wealth for the greater good, and they can surely agree that the system is currently stacked in their  favor.
But they ARE unequal.  Indeed, they are nothing alike as Santorum rightly expresses.

Thank you, Mr. Bruni. Please keep writing columns like this.
And please rebut those colleagues, like Mr. Douthat, who perpetuate maintaining unequal status for same-sex relationships. You should bring it up during your film conversations.

this is not about girls who want to drive trucks or boys who want to be ballet dancers.  this is about people who look in the mirror and see breasts where there should be a flat chest, smooth hairless skin where there should be a beard.  its when you hear your own voice in a pitch that doesn't match how you feel yourself to be.  I'm proud to be a transman with a soft spot for "chick" flics and a seemingly unending need to communicate my feelings with others, which are stereotypical female traits.  I am not any less of a man just because I haven't shunned everything female from my life.  I eagerly await the day my beard grows in, and my body reflects the secondary male sex characteristics I cannot achieve without testosterone.  but that doesn't mean I can't be nurturing, or that suddenly i must become a beer drinking football watching Jock.  I always was a man even when i had long hair and wore feminine clothes, its just that now my body reflects the male characteristics i was lacking, that gave me body dysphoria

Hillary Clinton is a leader in her own right and was masterful in helping Mr. Clinton achieve goals behind the scenes. She will make a very good president and that is exactly why republican commentors like Akbar attempt to vilify her. She will be getting my vote.

First, Senator Warren is not electable. Second, Hillary's time spent as Secretary of State was to burnish her foreign policy credentials. She accomplished little for the country beyond padding her resume.

Both Clintons have always been opportunists. She's just not as skilled and likable as he is.
I think Hillary was doing well before she met Bill and has done well since.  Contrary to your opinion, I think she had a very tough assignment cleaning up after the last President's fiasco.

Mrs. Clinton is an empty suit. Her greatest achievement was marrying an exceptional man, President Clinton. The former President was never a put-on. Mrs. Clinton is a perfect phony. She has no foreign or domestic policy. Her foreign policy must be imported from Israel!

President Obama greatest mistake was selecting Mrs. Clinton as Secretary of States. Thanks to her, we have a shamble in Syria and ISIS in Libya, Iraq, and Syria. She also voted for the Iraq war.

A bright person does not need 200 policy experts to plan her agenda. Ask her to name three major policy, and she would call Wall Street to receive a typed reply.

We need Senator Warren as future President, a fighter for the fallen, unloved and Middle Class.
